4.4 Arnauld’s criticism of Malebranche’s occasionalism

Arnauld opened a different line of attack in his Dissertation sur
les miracles le l’ancien loi. This new attack is directed
against the occasionalism which is assumed in Malebranche’s
account of the wisdom of God’s ways of creating. In a foreword
to the Dissertation, Arnauld says that he had completed his
treatment of the first two books of the Réflexions,
and was beginning work on the third, when he received the fourth
edition of the
 Treatise:[30]

I had finished two books examining the new system of nature and grace,
and there remained only one further book to complete the task, when I
received from Rotterdam a new edition of the Treatise,
published that year, 1684, with several additions. The main one was a
third Éclaircissement, with the title: The
frequent miracles of the Old Law do not at all indicate that God often
acts by particular volitions. And the only reason which the
author of the system gives is that the miracles were done by the
ministry of the angels, who were their occasional causes.


Arnauld interrupted his work on the Réflexions to
write the Dissertation, which was published in 1685 together
with the first chapter of Book Three of the Reflexions, a
chapter dealing with Malebranche’s position that Jesus Christ,
in his human nature, is the occasional cause of the distribution of
grace. Arnauld raises theological objections to both positions, but
also attacks the underlying occasionalism. The Dissertation
touched off a rapid series of replies and ounter-replies in 1685. The
first volume of Reflexions was published later in 1685, and
the second and third volumes in 1686.

Arnauld begins his attack by citing the opening sentence of the
Dernier Éclaircissement, in which Malebranche says
that he expects his readers to agree with the principle that
“God causes (fait) everything, and hence He
communicates His power to creatures only by establishing them as
occasional causes…” (OM, 5, 197). Arnauld adds that
Malebranche

does not understand ‘God causes everything’ as ordinary
philosophers do, who say that the creature does not act at all unless
God acts with it, which they call ‘concurrence’ …
But what he means when he says that God causes everything is that He
causes everything that one imagines the creature causes, and that the
creature causes nothing at all.


It is not difficult, Arnauld says, to show that the first conjunct, so
understood, is false. For “it destroys the nature of intelligent
beings, who would not be free if they did not, as real causes, form in
themselves the determination of their will toward particular
goods”. (As Arnauld points out, the italicized words are
Malebranche’s.) The second conjunct of the principle is
dispatched in a similar way:

For intelligent beings receive from God their power to form the
determination of their will toward particular goods. But it is not
only as occasional causes but as real causes that they form in
themselves that determination of their will. (OA, 5, 198)


Having established to his satisfaction that the principle “taken
generally” is false, Arnauld goes on to say that there is no
reason to deny that God has given angels power to move bodies and that
they are real, not mere occasional, causes of the miraculous events
attributed to them. Again, “it is not so easy to
demonstrate” that our soul does not have the real power to move
the parts of the body to which it is united.

In the exchange of publications that grew out of the
Dissertation, Arnauld objects in a similar way to
Malebranche’s use of occasionalism to explain “how grace
acts in us without wounding [liberty]” (OM, 5, 8). In his
explanation, Malebranche distinguishes the effect of grace, which is
from God and is not free, from the recipient’s free response,
which is from the recipient and not from God. Arnauld says that
Malebranche would have done well to heed Aquinas’s advice that
one should not distinguish “between what is from grace and what
is from free will, as if the same thing could not be from both”
(OA, 39, 114).

Both Malebranche and Arnauld continued to write about divine causality
and human freedom in their later work. Arnauld’s late work on
the topic is describe in Section 6 below. Malebranche’s last
effort on the topic was his Réflexions sur la Premotion
Physique, published in 1715, the year of his death.
